In Japan, where the death penalty is reserved for the most heinous crimes, violent crime rates remain among the lowest in the world. This is not a coincidence. The death penalty also brings closure to victims' families and society at large. In conclusion, the death penalty is not only a just punishment for the most severe crimes, but it also serves as the most effective deterrent available. The fear of death is the most powerful deterrent of all, and that is why the death penalty works where life imprisonment simply cannot.
